[[File:Sub-Saharan-Africa GHI mid-size-map 156x192mm-300dpi v20170928.png|thumb|upright=1.5|Global Horizontal Irradiation in Sub-Saharan Africa.{{Cite web|url=https://globalsolaratlas.info/|title=Global Solar Atlas|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|url-status=|access-date=6 December 2018}}]] [[File:Middle-East-and-North-Africa GHI mid-size-map 220x119mm-300dpi v20170928.png|thumb|upright=2|Global Horizontal Irradiation in North Africa and the Middle East.]] Africa is often considered and referred as the "Sun continent" or the continent where the Sun's influence is the greatest.{{cite book|title=The Atlas of African Affairs|author=Griffiths, I.L.|date=2013|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9781135855529|url=https://books.google.com/?id=8C40QP8vyU0C&pg=PA15|page=15|accessdate=2017-01-29}} According to the "World Sunshine Map", Africa receives many more hours of bright sunshine during the course of the year than any other continent of the Earth:{{cite book|title=Journal for Star Wisdom 2013|author1=Powell, R.|author2=Bowden, D.|author3=Tresemer, D.|author4=Bento, W.|author5=Farrants, W.|author6=Gray, B.|author7=Dann, K.|author8=Paul, L.|author9=Lainson, C.M.L.|author10=Nurney, S.|date=2012|publisher=Lindisfarne Books|isbn=9781584201366|url=https://books.google.com/?id=seofxcSzO0QC&pg=PT38|accessdate=2017-01-29}} many of the sunniest places on the planet lie there.{{cite web|url=http://www.currentresults.com/Weather-Extremes/sunniest-places-countries-world.php|publisher=currentresults.com|title=Sunniest Places and Countries in the World - Current Results|accessdate=2017-01-29}} Despite the large solar potential, penetration of solar power in Africa's energy sector is still very low.{{cite web|title=A Snapshot of Global PV (1992-2015)|url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/fileadmin/dam/public/report/statistics/IEA-PVPS_-__A_Snapshot_of_Global_PV_-_1992-2015_-_Final.pdf|publisher=IEA|accessdate=2016-12-05}} ==Solar potential== The whole continent has a long duration of sunshine, and excluding the large areas of tropical rainforests (the [[Guinean Forests of West Africa]] and much of the [[Congo Basin]]), since desert and savannah regions of Africa stand up as Earth's largest cloud-free area.{{cite book|title=Exploring Human Geography: A Reader|author1=Daniels, S.|author2=Lee, R.|date=2014|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9781317859222|url=https://books.google.com/?id=uYp9AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA425|page=425|accessdate=2017-01-29}} Africa is dominated by clear skies even beyond deserts (ex : [[Sahara]], [[Namib]], [[Kalahari]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/articles/thirteen-years-of-cloud-cover-in-one-beautiful-map/50928/|publisher=theweathernetwork.com|title=News - Thirteen years of cloud cover, in one beautiful map - The Weather Network|accessdate=2017-01-29}} however, the regions located along the equator are considerably cloudier than the tropics and subtropics. The eastern Sahara/northeastern Africa is particularly noted for its world sunshine records. The area experiences some of the greatest mean annual duration of bright sunshine,{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/guinnessbookofwe00holf|url-access=registration|quote=sahara.|title=The Guinness Book of Weather Facts and Feats|first=Ingrid|last=Holford|date=July 1, 1977|publisher=Guinness Superlatives|via=Internet Archive|isbn=9780900424755}} as the sun shines bright during approximatively as much as 4,300 hours a year,{{cite book|title=A Dictionary of Weather|author=Dunlop, S.|date=2008|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=9780191580055|url=https://books.google.com/?id=27DdCC-nSCEC&pg=PT524|accessdate=2017-01-29}} which is equal to 97% of the possible total.{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/guinnessbookofwe00holf|url-access=registration|quote=4300.|title=The Guinness Book of Weather Facts and Feats|first=Ingrid|last=Holford|date=July 1, 1977|publisher=Guinness Superlatives|via=Internet Archive|isbn=9780900424755}} This region also has the highest mean annual values of solar radiation{{cite book|title=World Weather Extremes|author1=Riordan, P.|author2=Paul G. Bourget|author3=U.S. Army Engineer Topographic Laboratories|date=1985|publisher=The Laboratories|isbn=9780788115370|url=https://books.google.com/?id=WNwaggeEz-cC&pg=PA66|page=66|accessdate=2017-01-29}}{{cite book|title=Climate and Life|date=1974|publisher=Elsevier Science|isbn=9780080954530|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ln89Y-6KwZYC&pg=PA151|page=151|accessdate=2017-01-29}} (the maximum recorded being over 220 kcal/cm2{{cite book|title=Forest Production for Tropical America|author1=Wadsworth, F.H.|author2=United States. Forest Service|date=1997|publisher=U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service|url=https://books.google.com/?id=RAIUAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=2017-01-29}}). The low latitude of the landmass is another asset: much of the continent lies in the intertropical zone, where the intensity and the strength of the sunlight are always high. The area contains lots of vast sun-drenched arid and semi-arid expanses in the north, in the south, and to a lesser extent in the east. About two fifths of the continent are desert, and thus continuously sunny. The combination of all these geographical and climatic factors is the cause of the large solar potential of Africa. The number of days of sunlight allows the potential of bringing solar power to much of Africa without large scale grid infrastructure.{{Cite book|last=Othieno, Herick|title=Energy resources in Africa : distribution, opportunities and challenges|publisher=|others=Awange, Joseph L., 1969-|date=16 October 2015|isbn=978-3-319-25187-5|location=Cham|pages=19|oclc=925521900}} The distribution of solar resources across Africa is fairly uniform, with more than 85% of the continent's landscape receiving a global solar horizontal irradiation at or over 2,000 kWh/(m2 year).{{citation| url=http://www.desertec.org/downloads/med-csp_en.pdf |title=Concentrating Solar Power for the Mediterranean Region |author= German Aerospace Center, Institute of Technical Thermodynamics, Section Systems Analysis and Technology Assessment |date=April 2005}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bosmos.com/home/sunlight|publisher=bosmos.com|title=Free, clean solar energy year-round |accessdate=2017-01-29}}{{citation |url=http://solargis.info/doc/index.php?select=71 |title=Solar Radiation Maps: Global Horizontal Irradiation (GHI) |publisher=Solar GIS}} Also, the theoretical reserves of Africa's solar energy are estimated at 60,000,000 TWh/year, which accounts for almost 40% of the global total, thus definitely making Africa the most sun-rich continent in the world.{{cite book|title=Global Energy Interconnection|author=Liu, Z.|date=2015|publisher=Elsevier Science|isbn=9780128044063|url=https://books.google.com/?id=T_MQCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA30|page=30|accessdate=2017-01-29}} ==Solar photovoltaics== [[File:Solar Power Plant Keetmanshoop.jpg|thumb|Solar Power Plant near [[Keetmanshoop]], [[Namibia]]]] Declining solar equipment costs are expected to significantly increase solar installations in Africa with an industry projection forecasting that the continent's annual PV market will expand to 2.2 GW by 2018.{{cite web |url= http://www.solarbuzz.com/news/recent-findings/middle-east-and-africa-solar-pv-demand-grow-50-percent-2014-according-npd-solar |title= Middle East and Africa Solar PV Demand to Grow by 50 Percent in 2014, According to NPD Solarbuzz |author= |publisher=[[NPD Group]] |date=2014-04-24 |accessdate=2014-08-19}} Future installations for harvesting solar energy in Africa will tend not to be found within the equatorial and subequatorial climate zones, that are located in the western part of Central Africa usually near the equator but that extend as far north and south as the 8th or 9th [[parallel (latitude)|parallel]] in both hemispheres, since they are systematically linked with almost permanent cloud cover and only intermittent bright sunshine. Therefore, countries that entirely lie in this wet-humid zone such as the [[Republic of the Congo]], [[Equatorial Guinea]], [[Gabon]], [[Rwanda]], [[Uganda]], [[Burundi]], [[Liberia]] and [[Sierra Leone]] are by far the least favoured in solar power of all the continent and except for these eight quoted nations, each other African country experiences over 2,700 hours of bright sunshine on at least a part of its territory. Many perpetually sunny African nations like [[Egypt]], [[Libya]], [[Algeria]], [[Niger]], [[Sudan]], [[South Africa]] and [[Namibia]] for instance could rely on developing their tremendous solar resources on a large scale thanks to the immense surface of their territory and at reduced prices. South Africa is a leader in solar power in Africa with 1329 MW installed by 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nersa.org.za/ReadNews.aspx?NewsID=325|title=Monitoring of Renewable Energy Performance 2016|website=www.nersa.org.za|access-date=2017-06-03}} [[Solar power in South Africa]] is rapidly growing. Several 75 MW PV plants and 2 CSP plants at 100 MW each were the largest in the country and among the largest in Africa. South Africa has announced a plan to install a minigrid on [[Robben Island]]; adding PV and battery storage is predicted by reduce diesel usage by half.[http://www.decentralized-energy.com/articles/2017/10/south-africa-s-robben-island-to-be-solar-powered.html South Africa’s Robben Island to be solar powered], Decentralized Power, Diarmaid Williams, 23/10/2017 A 50 MW photovoltaic power plant is planned for [[Garissa]] in [[Kenya]], a city located at the equator where the sun is said to shine for about 3,144 hours each year on average, and it is expected to produce approximately 76,473 MWh/year.{{cite web|url=http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/article-281/chinese-firms-build-solar-power-plant-garissa|publisher=the-star.co.ke|title= Chinese firms to build solar power plant in Garissa |accessdate=2017-01-29}} A 155 MW photovoltaic power plant is planned for [[Ghana]] and the government plans to increase solar power in the country from 22.5MW in 2017 to 300MW in 2020.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20583663|publisher=bbc.co.uk|title=Ghana solar energy plant set to be Africa's largest - BBC News|accessdate=2017-01-29}}[https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/business/Government-targets-300MW-of-solar-by-2020-584389 Government targets 300MW of solar by 2020], GhanaWeb, 25 September 2017 There are also many small-scale modular solar power installations being implemented across the continent at the village and household levels.{{cite journal | last1 = Kemeny | first1 = P | last2 = Munro | first2 = P G | last3 = Schiavone | first3 = N | last4 = van der Horst | first4 = G | last5 = Willans | first5 = S | title = Community Charging Stations in rural sub-Saharan Africa: Commercial success, positive externalities, and growing supply chains | journal = Energy for Sustainable Development | volume = 23 | pages = 228–236 | date = 2014| doi = 10.1016/j.esd.2014.09.005 }} In 2015, [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] was the leading region for purchases of off-grid solar products.[http://www.ren21.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/GSR_2016_Full_Report.pdf Renewables 2016 Global Status Report], 428 |- |} ==Solar thermal power== [[File:KhiSolarOneBirdView.jpg|thumb|Bird's eye view of [[Khi Solar One]] (October 2016)
Focusing light above the tower]] The Kingdom of [[Solar power in Morocco|Morocco’s solar plan]], which is one of the world’s largest solar energy projects and estimated to cost about $9 billion, was introduced in November 2009 with the aim of establishing 2,000 MW of solar power by 2020. Five sites have been selected for the development of solar power plants combining a number of technologies including [[concentrated solar power]], [[parabolic trough]] as well as [[photovoltaics]], with the 500MW phase one solar power complex at Ouarzazate being the first to be developed.{{cite web|url=http://masen.org.ma/index.php?Id=42&lang=en#/_|publisher=masen.org.ma|title=masen.org.ma/index.php?Id=42&lang=en#/_|access-date=2017-01-29|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314222608/http://masen.org.ma/index.php?Id=42&lang=en#/_|archive-date=2016-03-14|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://ecogeek.org/component/content/article/3770|publisher=ecogeek.org|title=ecogeek.org/component/content/article/3770|access-date=2017-01-29|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924062425/http://ecogeek.org/component/content/article/3770|archive-date=2014-09-24|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/publications/mtmr/countries/morocco/|publisher=iea.org|title=IEA - 404 Not Found|accessdate=2017-01-29}} The first part of the 500MW project, the 160MW Noor I came online in 2016 and uses [[parabolic trough]] [[concentrated solar power]] technology.{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/02/04/morocco-solar-idUKL5N0L92J220140204|author=Reuters Editorial | publisher=uk.reuters.com | title=Morocco says investors lining up for $9 bln solar project | Reuters|accessdate=2017-01-29}} Morocco, the only African country to have a power cable link to Europe, aims to benefit from energy sales to Europe. One such initiative was [[Desertec]].{{cite web|url=http://www.solargcc.com/morocco-solar/|publisher=solargcc.com|title=Morocco Solar | Solar GCC|accessdate=2017-01-29}} South Africa has developed several solar thermal plants, both parabolic trough and power tower types. In 2017, it was the leading country in Africa for both solar thermal and PV solar energy. ==See also== {{Portal|Renewable energy}} * [[Solar power in Algeria]] * [[Solar power in Morocco]] * [[Solar power in South Africa]] * [[Renewable energy in Africa]] * [[Solar power by country]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Africa topic|Solar power in|noredlinks=yes}} {{Renewable energy by country}} [[Category:Solar power by country|*]] [[Category:Renewable energy in Africa]]
